thread.title: Clinton's campaign chair takes jabs at two of her male opponents
thread.title_full: Clinton's campaign chair takes jabs at two of her male opponents | Washington Examiner

author: Gabby Morrongiello
title: Clinton's campaign chair takes jabs at two of her male opponents
text:
During an interview Sunday with ABC's George Stephanopoulos, Hillary Clinton's campaign chairman took aim at two of her male opponents: Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders and Republican front-runner Donald Trump.
John Podesta claimed that Sanders appeared to change courses during the Iowa Democratic Party's annual Jefferson-Jackson dinner Saturday, and welcomed a general election match-up featuring Clinton and Trump.
"I think Bernie Sanders seemed to have a course correction in the dinner from one in which he said he wasn't going to go negative to obviously focusing his, you know, his fire on [Clinton]," Podesta said Sunday on ABC's "This Week."
In comparison to the socialist senator from Vermont, Podesta said Clinton's remarks at the dinner were centered around her vision for the country as opposed to her differences with other candidates.
  Poll: 85 percent of voters think the U.S. is on wrong track Additionally,     fragile."
By Gabby Morrongiello • 10/25/15 5:46 PM "I think she's looking to the future [and] her speech last night really put forward a positive vision of where the country can be," Podesta said.
Later, the former chief of staff to former President Bill Clinton told Stephanopoulos a toe-to-toe competition between the former secretary of state and Trump "works very well" for the Clinton campaign.
"Moving forward, if he's the nominee of the Republican Party, I think that's a matchup that works very well for us," he said, adding, "She's out listening to the American people, offering real solutions, talking about the fight she'll fight for them, and he's out, you know, hurling insults."
Clinton, who leads Sanders by roughly 23 percentage points in the latest RealClearPolitics polling average , avoided committing any major gaffes during her 11-hour testimony Thursday before the House Select Committee on Benghazi. The former first lady also emerged as the winner of last week's Democratic primary debate, and was endorsed Saturday by David Plouffe, who ran President Obama's 2008 presidential campaign.
"We feel very good about where we are today in terms of winning the nomination," Podesta told ABC.
